channel.title: Comments on: Do not disable foreign keys
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Todd Everett
item.dc:creator: Todd Everett
item.description: Great post - sad this is so universally true. Back in the day we used to tell the naive developer, in the words of Johnny Bravo - "I've got 2 words for you mister - NO." Your example of how straight forward it actually is to resolve the situation correctly is excellent.
item.content:encoded: Great post – sad this is so universally true. Back in the day we used to tell the naive developer, in the words of Johnny Bravo – “I’ve got 2 words for you mister – NO.” Your example of how straight forward it actually is to resolve the situation correctly is excellent.

item.title: By: chopstik
item.dc:creator: chopstik
item.content:encoded:
Foreign keys? We don’t need no stinkin’ foreign keys… ðŸ™‚

But this has been a persistent issue I’ve encountered so will be forwarding this to some people I know. Thanks.

item.title: By: George Mastros (gmmastros)
item.dc:creator: George Mastros (gmmastros)
item.description: It's already a part of SQLCop.

item.title: By: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.dc:creator: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.description: Oh, imagine the person that forgets to re-enable them after doing something as horrid as this. Maybe a good check for SQLCop? Or is it already in there
item.content:encoded: Oh, imagine the person that forgets to re-enable them after doing something as horrid as this. Maybe a good check for SQLCop? Or is it already in there

item.title: By: George Mastros (gmmastros)
item.dc:creator: George Mastros (gmmastros)
item.content:encoded:
I thought I’d add my 2 cents.

You can determine which foreign keys are disabled with this code:

Select object_name(parent_object_id) As TableName,
name As ForeignKeyName
From sys.foreign_keys
Where is_ms_shipped = 0 and is_disabled = 1
